markdownRemark.html:
Read about my OCD of doing things by the book and how it causes me anxiety and plagues my ability to get anything done.

I’m not sure if there’s a word for this, but I enjoy doing things as real as possbile, maybe better put, done by the book. It’s hard for me to articulate what exactly I mean by that, so for the purpose of this post, I’ll explain one simple and contrived example that I’ve come across recently.

Think of a website, any website. I just thought of Twitter. Now, visit the site in mind locate the footer of the site. There you will most likely see multiple links, probably some about the product, the company, the legal things, etc. I’d bet there is also a statement that looks somewhere along the lines of:

© <year> <company_name>

Am I right? You may be wondering, “Why is Cedric writing about footer copyright notices?” Let me explain. My current side project is called unearth and recently I have been designing and coding the landing page. Now, when I got to the footer, I wanted to do things as real as possible and decided to throw in the aforementioned copyright noteice, to make things look legit, you know? This is the crazy part.

Initially, I put © 2019 Unearth. A few minutes later, I thought, “Is that even legal? What is Unearth, I don’t actually own a company named Unearth.” After spending a few more minutes looking for inspiration, I decided to change “Unearth” to “Unearth Labs” because that’s what Notion (notion.so) does.
